eapli.framework.domain.ddd

Interface DomainEntity<I>

  • Type Parameters:
    I - the type of the primary business id of the entity
    All Superinterfaces:
    Identifiable<I>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    AggregateRoot<I>

    public interface DomainEntity<I>
extends Identifiable<I>
    An entity is a Domain-Driven Design pattern for concepts in the domain which have a thread of continuity which needs to be tracked. These concepts matter by their identity and we need to track them continuously. Instance equality must be done thru the identity of the objects and we cannot loose track or allow duplication of an entity. By definition a domain entity always has a business identity, so it should be impossible to create new instances without identity. Typical examples are:
    1. Product
    2. Person
    3. Account
    Author:
    Paulo Gandra Sousa

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean equals(Object other)
      Entities are compared by identity only. no need to compare all fields of the object. you can use the domainEntityHelper.areEqual() method as default implementation see sameAs().
      int hashCode()
      hash code of this object according to java rules. i.e., the same fields used in equals() should be used in hashCode().
      boolean sameAs(Object other)
      Entities are compared by identity only, so equals() only compares identities. in some situations however we might want to compare the content of the object.
